reviewText:
Time Disclaimer -- I have played 911: First Responders / Emergency 4 for hundreds of hours prior to the Steam release.

Emergency 4 is a Real Time Strategy in which the user is tasked with controlling a number of German Emergency Services; Police, Ambulance, Fire, and Mechanics. Using these, it's up to the user to deal with a number of disasters in the main campaign ranging from simple fires to earthquakes, hostage situations, airline disasters and more! Alternatively, the user can play an endless mode in which they must deal with random emergencies which will grant them the finances to purchase more vehicles and deal with bigger disasters. One great aspect is you're not penalized for doing a bad job so if you get bored, you can use your police units to cause havoc.

The game is easy to get into but difficult to master as controlling a number of different emergency units can quickly become overwhelming. The assets have also aged well since release.

Emergency 4 is definitely a unique game and is an often looked over gem, it's a game that is both engaging and enjoyable, even if you're not a fan of Real Time Strategies.

Additionally, the game is VERY moddable. The 'LA Mod[losangelesmod.com]' is definitely recommended as it adds dozens of additional units and missions.

To put it simply, this game is a must play and for the price it's being offered at, it's definitely worth grabbing. There are rumors of emegency 5 being released next month (October 2014) and hopefully it's a better game than the poorly done Emergency 2012/2013/2014 games and hopefully, the release of Emergency 4 on Steam is a good sign of Emergency 5 being released on Steam sometime soon.

reviewText:
At first glance, this game might look like those abysmal simulator games that you find decorating the local GameStop's bargain bin and the Steam Greenlight page in equal measure. However, 911: First Responders couldn't be more different. What appears to be a mild-mannered and simple simulation is a surprisingly realistic and hair-pullingly tough game of skill and judgement that plays out more like an RTS than a traditional sim. Well-researched subject material, a lengthy and challenging campaign, and exquisite sound and music design go hand-in-hand to create this gem of a game that deserves far more recognition than first appearances might suggest.

In 911: First Responders, the player assumes the role of an emergency dispatcher in an unidentified, accident-prone urban sprawl somewhere in Europe - presumably the Netherlands, considering where developers Sixteen Tons Entertainment hail from. It's your sole duty to command and micro-manage emergency responders of all professions and roles, ranging from police marksmen to fire department marine divers to tow truck technicians. The mammoth campaign is comprised of twenty assignments that are broken up by short sessions of responding to low-level emergency calls inside the city, with each success granting the player some of the funds needed to buy vehicles and upgrades that are imperative for the next big assignment. Though they start out easy enough, these large-scale missions quickly become damningly hard and will push even experienced RTS players to their multi-tasking, micro-managing limits. A very wide range of emergency situations and responses are represented in loving detail, giving the game just enough complexity to be engaging without being overwhelming to people who aren't educated in emergency service operations - despite the plethora of vehicles and personnel on hand, most of the tools the player is given have an obvious and easily comprehensible application. The open-ended nature of each assignment is also something to be noted and applauded - though some missions may have clear solutions, others require creative use of the tools at your disposal in order to save  as many lives as possible.

Of course, fun as it is, the game isn't flawless. The eight-year-old graphics can't help but show their age upon close examination (though they aren't 'bad' by any means), and the pathfinding of the game's larger vehicles can become problematic in enclosed areas - which feature heavily in some assignments, occasionally resulting in Tetris-like scenes in which the player must manually guide their confused emergency vehicles out of a tight spot in order to release an urgently-needed automotive at the bottom of the metaphorical heap. The game also has a nasty habit of giving the player new tools or personnel without giving much notification, which wouldn't be so bad if those new tools and personnel didn't tend to play very critical roles in the mission in which you're given them. One notable example is the fifth assignment, in which the player must clean up after a road bridge collapse - a task in which the fire brigade's marine divers are essential for locating sunken cars in the river below. The game, of course, doesn't tell you that it's given you these divers, so they're easy to miss when you're loading up a fire engine to send onto the map.

These flaws, however, pale greatly against the immense fun that I've been having with this game so far. The surprisingly steep challenges that it offers seriously surprised me as I progressed further into the campaign, and part of what motivates me to overcome every nail-bitingly tense challenge and assignment is my curiosity over what the next assignment will hold.  At the asking price of £3.99, this game is an absolute steal for its quality and a must for strategy fans and anyone who's enthusiastic about the work of the emergency services. Definitely get this game.

reviewText:
911: First Responders is one of those little gems you pick up in the “dollar bin” not realizing what you’ve found, let it sit on your shelf for a few months, and when you finally get around to playing it you almost feel like you owe it an apology.

While this isn’t the best emergency response game I’ve ever played it is one of the most well rounded.  In a 911 title you’d expect to have units from the Police, Fire, and Medical fields but this game goes further.  It also brings in services like clean-up wreckers and specialty vehicles.  In addition, all of your vehicles have their specific roles to play in combating the events that occur in your city.

If I had one thing to nitpick about this game it would be that it’s too busy, specifically in the “nonstop” mode.  This mode is almost like a sandbox where you are given event after event to deal with.  The problem here is that occasionally an event is so complicated, like a bush fire, that it takes you a while to deal with it.  While combating that bush fire you may end up getting assigned another fire, or a police action.  This leaves you either losing ground in your complicated task while you deal with the others, or ignoring the others and completing your complicated task.  The limit on how many vehicles you can have active at once also hinders the ability to deal with multiple emergencies

Things get a little better in multiplayer mode, but not much.  Yes, there is a multiplayer mode.  In this mode you and a friend can tackle emergencies in the same city.  The only downside here is that the ability to dispatch new vehicles is turn-based.  Players have to have good communication and use excellent team work in “passing the torch” so their partner can help dispatch vehicles to emergencies without delay.  Once the vehicles are on the map, however, you don’t need control of dispatch in order to maneuver them around.  You do, however, need to return them to headquarters so vehicles are available for other emergencies.

Graphically this game is pretty good.  The game plays out in a somewhat 3D map view of the entire city.  You can easily use the mini-map to jump around the city, or scroll off the side with your mouse.  The level of detail is pretty good, as you’ll find yourself needing to access everything from equipment in the vehicles to fire hydrants.  Doors have to be broken down.  Hostages have to be rescued.  Fire victims have to be rescued from buildings.  Injured have to be extricated from vehicles and treated by medics.  It’s a fairly involved game for the graphics being so “zoomed out”.  I never really found myself fighting the camera, it was fairly easy to control and rotate around structures.

Sound in the game got somewhat repetitive after a while.  There is one announcement for each type of emergency, and it’s repeated every time the specific emergency happens.  Music is fast paced but also gets a little repetitive at times.  Still, it suits the theme of the game and brings in a little bit of excitement.

All in all… I have to refer to my opening statement.  When I got this game I wasn’t expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised.

reviewText:
I wish there was a middle ground between recommending and not recommending, but until such time as that exists, I will stick to my status of 'not-recommending'. But with some positive points.

Allow me to clarify:

I see a lot of positive reviews for this game, and I know it was a product of its era, but I really struggle to wrap my brain around this one. Aside from a few issues where save games were mysteriously deleted, I found that before I could get my hands on a campaign mission I had to wade through inane emergency after inane emergency.

Quick! Someone's had a fall and has a minor injury! (A minor injury? Like a sprained ankle? Fine, they can wait while I tend to the three fires going on and the pickpocket on the loose) - I return a minute or two later and find that the person had DIED from their minor injury

I eventually did get into the campaign and tried the first two 'levels' - but really it seems that there is a formula for dealing with them, and deviating *at all* makes things difficult.

Pathfinding is ridiculous - roads are a mere suggestion - and I know there's the ages-old argument about depth vs simplicity, but requesting a fire truck, then waiting for it, then selecting it when it arrives, then clicking near to the fire emergency, then asking your firefighters to get out, then asking your firefighters to equip themselves with fire hoses, then asking your firefighters to attach their equipped fire hoses to separate fire hydrants dotted around the area, THEN finally asking them to put out the fire (Though the hitbox often means you end up cooling a building and not attacking the fire), it does get rather tiresome. When the fire is out , reasonably you'd expect them to tackle any other fires in their immediate vicinity, but no, they will stand about and wait for the order - often while you're doing other things - so the fire spreads yet further. THEN once the fire is out, you tell your firefighters to disconnect the hoses, put the gear away, then get back in the vehicle before either shuttling them to the next fire or sending them back to HQ.

It is very difficult to manage time in this game, and completing campaigns often means failing them often enough until you know the formula. It's a very stressful game at the best of times!

I really can see the appeal, and Hardcore RTS fans may very well be all over this, but this game is not for me, and certainly not one I'd recommend for the casual or average gamer...!

THAT ALL SAID - apparently there are plenty of mods which make this game a lot more playable. To those who have time for such endeavours - I wish you luck!

As usual, I have documented my progress in the form of a video playlist:

This is my introduction to the Emergency series, and I am blown away! It's such a simple concept- respond to various situations and instruct your crew to save lives. And yet, it's nearly impossible to master. I will send an ambulance to a seemingly ordinary cardiac arrest call, but in minutes, the whole block could be up in flames because a bomb went off!

There is a wide array of emergency vehicles to dispatch, and each have their own advantages. It's up to you to learn them. It can definately be challenging and frustrating at times (I once had a riot that had over 50 causalties to attend to), but it's a fun game with many hours of replayability. The campaign mode is fun and immersive (while challenging).

Yes, the game does have a few flaws. Occasionally, you may experience a crash. Other times, the graphic interface may flicker. There is definitely room to improve on, which is why I can't wait to buy the newest of the series.

It is worth the $5- I have personally invested 12 hours as of this review, and won't be quitting soon.
